first_story_block:
You’re watching porn at home, in teenage bliss,
When some fool starts texting—oh, it’s your Sis.
“I can’t drive right now, come and get me,” she says
Sometimes, you really hate that fat stupid lez.

Christmas party with friends, she’d be safe, she swore.
But her friends might as well be two dollar whores.
And so you play the hero, when she gets lit.
Sucks, but now you gotta deal with this shit.

Resigned, you grab keys, slam the door of the car,
Check address and sigh; this place is pretty far.
A manse in the woods, sounds like a bad movie.
Yet there you must go, to rescue that floozie.

action_results.result:
More texts arrive, as the road enters the trees,
“Blake, things are getting kind of weird, hurry please.”
“Most of my friends seem to be sick or in pain,”
“But don’t call the cops, we’ve had lots of cocaine.”

Well here you are! This old mansion is creepy.
Katie better be real sorry and weepy.
No one cares to answer, when you ring the bell.
So you just let yourself in. Might as well.

This place, for a party, it’s oddly quiet?
Though they sure trashed the place; looks like a riot.
Yet you see no one around, where’d they all go?
There’s two places to search, up high or down low.

Ascending the stairs, they creak and they shiver.
If you break your neck, you’ll never forgive her.
Stench up here recalls wet dog, stains on the floor,
Just past the landing, something bangs at a door.

“Katie?” you ask, giving the brass knob a turn.
Just a bit too hasty, a fact you soon learn.
Your motives were good. Well, goodish, at least,
But the last thing seen are the teeth of a beast.

You’re watching porn at home, in teenage bliss,
When some fool starts texting—oh, it’s your Sis.
“I can’t drive right now, come and get me,” she says
Sometimes, you really hate that fat stupid lez.

Christmas party with friends, she’d be safe, she swore.
But her friends might as well be two dollar whores.
And so you play the hero, when she gets lit.
Sucks, but now you gotta deal with this shit.

Resigned, you grab keys, slam the door of the car,
Check address and sigh; this place is pretty far.
A manse in the woods, sounds like a bad movie.
Yet there you must go, to rescue that floozie.

The door shakes, it rattles, but doesn't quite roll,
A growl, and then, unearthly howls pierce your soul.
Something angry, heavy and large bangs against,
To back slowly away, seems good common sense.

Wow. Just Wow. Stupid must be genetic.
The screams that follow are quite pathetic.
Matted fur, red eyes, white fangs in dark muzzle,
Scatters your flesh like a jigsaw puzzle.

A wise choice, but it already has your scent,
Smashing door to splinters, the beast’s red eyes glint.
Twisted mockery of canine, teeth like knives.
Nothing to do now but run for your life.

Sprinting away, like a little girl you shriek,
Monster dashing behind in a furious streak,
Dead end up ahead. Oh no! Guess you’re fucked!
But wait, there’s a window, maybe you can jump!

The window is open, how lucky you are!
You roll off the roof, and then fall pretty far.
Thankfully the beast fears heights or something.
You stumble to your car, give the cops a ring.

Of course, no one believes a word you say,
And Katie is never seen past that day.
Her friends, gone too--at first the cops blame you,
Then change their tune, say there’s nothing they can do.

The government moves in, shuts down the whole site.
The suits pay a visit to your house, one night.
Have you sign papers, “Everything is fine!”
“It was all a delusion, just too much wine.”

Um. Okay. Not exactly sure of your plan,
But turn and face that monster, macho man.
Before you decide to fight or pray, you fall.
By doggy reduced to red slurry on wall.

Thinking fast, you pick a door and duck inside,
Beast growls without, you didn’t exactly hide.
But there must be some way to give it the slip,
Or your flesh and bones it surely will rip.

You think you saw this in a movie once,
So you lower yourself down, instead of lunch.
Now you’re on the first floor kitchen, but wait...
A strange girl is here with a zombie-like gait.

The girl turns to face you, blood on her mouth.
Just who the FUCK has she been eating out?
This girl is freaking you out, should you run?
Or is it time for your smoothest moves, my son?

“M’lady,” you start, but she seems unimpressed,
In your best fedora, if only you’d dressed.
But turns out she’s all over you anyway,
And then you died. What more is there to say?

You turn and dart down the hall, run past Kate...
Wait, what? Back up. Is this delusion or fate?
Something different about the way she walks,
Glinting in her eyes, oddness when she talks.

Be great to go home, but you're not sure of this.
"Katie? Is that you?" You squint suspicious.
She giggles, “It’s me! And thanks for the ride.”
But you can’t help but have certain doubts inside...

Well, “Don’t look a gift sister in the mouth.”
As a wise man once said. You think it was Proust?
Or maybe it wasn’t. You don’t really care.
You’re taking “Kate” outside, into the night air.

You know something is off. Her eyes are too bright.
The truth is, you were scared shitless that night.
Wander the evil house some more? Fuck that!
Now technically, everything is wrapped up pat.

And it’s all good, you like your new sister.
Just ignore that sunlight makes her skin blister.
‘Sides, this Kate doesn’t drink, not liquor at least.
And you sleep fine, with cross blessed by a priest.

“Just what the fuck is going on here?” you ask.
“Blake, don’t be silly!” ‘Kate’ has a strange laugh.
“Brother dear, let’s leave this place, forget this night.”
Now you know something’s up, Kat’s NEVER this nice.

“Tell me if you’re fake, I swear I won’t be mad.”
‘Kate’ shrugs a bit, even looks a little sad.
“I was trying to help,” she says with a purr,
“Your sister’s downstairs, but you’ll never find her.”

Then bright flash of light, and black cat runs away,
Probably to shit somewhere, then sleep all day.
But hey, ‘downstairs’, good idea no doubt,
Still hear snarling above, best to get out.

Descending the stairs, they creak when you walk.
It’s dark down here, but you’re too manly to balk.
“Anybody there? Your lights aren’t working.”
You helpfully call to anything lurking.

Lights flare to life, candles on skulls that glare,
Ooh, scary. You get it. You don’t fucking care.
Here’s a spooky pentagram scratched on the floor,
Why not just put ‘Satanists’ on the front door?

Shackles on a table and...is that blood real?
That’s incredibly unhygienic, you feel.
Whatever, find Katie, get out of here quick.
These people are into some really weird shit.

Next room, you find a book on a pedestal,
You touch it--the sensation regrettable.
Questionable leather stitched to the cover,
Rust-red runes, aura of wrong does hover.

You can’t quite make sense of the writing at first,
Till the text resolves into blasphemous verse.
Strange, writhing runes brand your flesh, start to glow.
Not quite sure, but you THINK you just sold your soul.

Now it ALL makes sense, you finally see clear,
Just claw out your eyes, and stab out your ears.
Man was not meant to witness abyssal planes,
Let all that dark knowledge leak out with your brains.

Yeah, this ain’t Skyrim, no mid-dungeon reading,
Just locate your sister, and get to leaving.
Finding Kate, easier said than done, of course.
It’s a maze down here, you yell till you’re hoarse.

No signal for texting to learn what the fuck,
It’s all down to you, your wits and your luck.
One hallway slopes downward, one ends at wall blank,
Footprints and a draft, a hidden door, you think.

So this entrance, it’s got to be here, let’s see...
If you were a secret door, where would you be?
Then...aha! You’ve got it! A loose brick clicks.
This batshit house can’t fool you with its tricks.

Come out on a balcony, take in the sights.
Below, a bizarre scene, it just ain’t right.
Dull red glow, eerie voices chanting.
Around a portal, robed figures dancing.

To a tattooed man, they seem to give credit,
Not a bad set up, if you can get it.
Prisoners, forced to bow to the man in charge,
Sis easy to recognize, she is...quite large.

Well! Time to free Kate, and be the big hero.
But, truth, you’ve never felt more like a zero.
You haven’t the slightest clue what to do.
Regardless, right now, it’s all up to you!

Searching the ledge for things stabby or shooty,
You stumble across unexpected booty.
Two strong, independent women, locked in cells,
How convenient, right there’s the key on a shelf.

“I’m Layne,” says the raven-haired beaut with red lips,
“I’ll kill that tattooed fuck and cut off his dick.”
“Don’t believe a word she says!” the other cries.
She’s a blonde, mommish type, big tits and blue eyes.

She shows you a badge. “I’m Linda, detective.”
“Layne is one of them, don’t trust her a second.”
Layne rolls her eyes. “I’m a vampire,” she claims.
“Ready to show these cultists a world of pain.”

You’re sure they both have backstories compelling,
Pathos to fill a novel best selling.
But to be distracted now, could death equal,
Save chatting up NPCs for the sequel.

So, who to choose? It’s quite the dilemma.
Officer MILF or the foxy killa?
Who can help the most, who can be trusted?
Make up your mind, before the lock’s rusted.

“Thanks! Now follow me, I know just what to do!”
Few bad guys around, but this chick knows kung fu.
She leads you to a secret weapon stash.
Boxes of ammo and shotguns that blast.

To mow cultists down you’re now fully equipped,
You take up positions, and let ‘er rip!
They seem surprised when you aim for their middles,
Rather upset, when with bullets they’re riddled.

Now, wonder what Linda’s up to over there?
Blows a hole in Tattoo’s chest, beyond repair.
Grabs a book from his side, begins to intone,
Some weird Latin shit, you don’t even know.

She steps toward the portal; it crackles with light.
“I always wanted to be Queen of the Night!
And Blake? By the way? You’re a gullible fuck.”
A wave and a laugh and she’s gone. Just your luck.

The ground rumbles, the walls tremble, the floor shakes.
(And other phrases to describe earthquakes.)
“Blake! What the hell! Hurry and undo this lock!”
Oh right. Katie, your sis. You almost forgot.

The cell key unlocks her chains, imagine that!
Someone Up Above must want to end this path.
The building’s still shaking, it’s time to bail!
The stairs make Kat wheeze like a dying whale.

Bursting out the front door, you did it, you’re free!
Well done! You win! A hero you’ll always be.
Make haste for the car, peel out in the drive.
Mansion sinks to Hell behind you, what a dive.

Kat is sorry, she picked such a bad party,
Her thanks are profuse, her gratitude hearty.
But ten minutes later, Katie is snoring.
Bitch forgets the whole thing, by the morning.

Unbelievable! Blake didn’t die.
Here, have a well-earned slice of pie.



(By the way, this is the best ending you’ll get,
Dodged a dozen much worse, you’re good at this shit.)

(Another aside, congrats, you unraveled,
the absolute longest pathway to travel.)

“Good choice. Now wait outside a moment, please.”
Reasonable request. You feel quite at ease.
There comes to your ear a sound like bones snapping,
Layne steps out, informs you Linda is napping.

“I’ll kill the cultists, stay beside me, don’t slip.”
Seems you’ve been downgraded to inept sidekick.
But vampire, sure. You let her do what she does,
And a guard is soon missing most of his blood.

When you reach the portal she really cuts loose,
Goes after Tattoo with no quarter or truce.
Fight’s pretty cool, they’re all flipping and shit,
You avoid cultists, try not to get hit.

Then...whoops! Layne gets skewered, though she’s not mortal,
Strong enough still, drags his ass through the portal.
They both disappear in a flash of bright light,
Ground starts to rumble, better call it a night.

Cultists are freaking out or whatever,
You go for Kat, try to keep it together.
“Blake! Get me out of here, this party’s the worst!
“No shit Sis, let’s go, ‘fore we leave in a hearse.”

Vaguely you hope this will end in a threesome,
But the ladies alas, just won’t see reason.
“Bloodsucker!” “Witch!” then both fall to fighting.
The ruckus draws in the guards like lightning.

Dashing out of a side door, bravely you run,
So much for help, now you’re back to square one.
But you suppose, while attention’s diverted,
You’ll free Kate, ‘fore cultists get perverted.

Low to the ground, action theme blaring in head,
Aren’t you precious. Just try not to wind up dead.
You can’t shake the feeling you look like a dweeb,
But soon you spot the distraction you need.


A pooch on a leash, like the pupper upstairs,
Looks raring to go, find someone to tear.
Unpredictable yeah, it’s taking a chance,
But he’d be just the thing to crash this dance.

In a moment you’re showered in bloody rain,
Fuckin dog cleans house like a hurricane.
You free Katie and friends, tell them to run,
Then oops, your foot slips, it looks like you’re done.

Hit the ground hard, get up in a hurry,
Pooch runnin’ towards you in a crimson flurry,
You dodge to the left, but should’ve gone right,
Knocked into the portal, it erupts with light.

Where you wind up, no one ever can say.
House up and vanishes, by dawn of day.
Katie feels real bad, for what has been done,
Decides to become a fat lesbian nun.

action_results.action: (Never mind. Just...throw a rock or something?)
action_results.result:
On second thought, it’s simpler to throw a rock.
Don’t need some crazy mutt to bite off your cock.
You find one, pitch it, but the cultists act wrong.
They don’t all swarm over there in a throng.

Worrisome how they now search for you.
Games were wrong. Not a stealthy thing to do.
Though now you wish you’d found a savepoint,
As these nutters grab you, your bones to disjoint.

Soft curtains of cobwebs, brush against hand,
Water drips, wet fetid air, hard to stand.
Uneasy feeling in pit of your stomach,
Then a sight ahead makes your heart plummet.

Massive chamber, webbed bodies, dangle in air,
Some rotting, some fresh, with fixed glassy stares.
Now THIS, this is bullshit. You cannot deal.
Turn back? Go on? You’ll piss yourself for real.

Wow, great idea! Keep digging in deeper,
This surely can’t lead to date with the Reaper.
In fact, Ol’ Grim, he’s beaten to the prize.
By chitinous mandibles, rows of green eyes.

Skittering down the wall, on too many legs,
What happens next involves breakfast, and eggs.
Really I’d rather not go into detail,
Spiders are scary, and sanity frail.

Yes. Let's leave, never think of this place again.
Now where's that secret door, how do you get in??
Then...aha! You’ve got it! A loose brick clicks.
This batshit house can’t fool you with its tricks.

Forgotten trinkets, cobwebbed shelves, layered dust,
Plethora of knickknacks, abandoned to rust.
In the last room, door slams, locks with a snikt,
A tall man stand there, he looks pretty ticked.

“A trespasser, I see. This displeases me.”
You start to stammer questions about Katie,
But...this man, so hot, you forget what to say.
So sexy, so pale, and you’re not even gay!

You stare awhile and feel quite mesmerized,
There’s just a certain...something, in his eyes.
“Go stand in the corner till I want a snack.
No mortal shall interrupt my fucking nap.”

This all seems quite reasonable, and while
He climbs in his coffin you can’t help but smile.
(Seems Katie is not getting saved after all,
Malleable Blakie is now some vampire’s thrall.)

Fleeing down old, steep stairs is tough for a man,
Four legs are better, so much for this plan.
Before halfway down, you’re savaged by hound,
Dead, quite dead, before you tumble to ground.

Descending the stairs, they creak when you walk.
It’s dark down here, but you’re too manly to balk.
“Anybody there? Your lights aren’t working.”
You helpfully call to anything lurking.

Light flickers on, candles on skulls that glower.
These must be eco-freaks, saving their power.
You spy a pentagram scratched on the floor,
Christmas now, so why the Halloween decor?
